metadata.paragraph_text_preview: This is one of several class action challenges to the Trump Administration's use of the Alien Enemie...

target:
This is one of several class action challenges to the Trump Administration's use of the Alien Enemies Act ("AEA") to circumvent removal procedures and deport Venezuelan nationals without due process. You can see all of the cases here [../../../../search/case/?advanced_search=true&plaintiff_description=Alien+Enemies+Act&ordering=-summary_approved_date].

On April 9, 2025, three Venezuelan men filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas. They named as respondents President Donald J. Trump, the Department of Justice, the Department of Homeland Security (“DHS”), Immigration and Customs Enforcement (“ICE”), the Department of State, and the El Valle Detention Facility, the Texas ICE facility where the petitioners are being held.

Represented by the ACLU, the petitioners challenged the Administration’s invocation of the AEA to remove them from the United States without any opportunity for a hearing or judicial review. The AEA is a wartime measure that authorizes the removal of citizens from countries with whom the United States is at war. On March 15, 2025, President Trump issued a proclamation declaring that the United States was “under invasion” by Tren de Aragua, a Venezuelan gang and designated foreign terrorist organization, and invoking the AEA.

The petitioners alleged that this use of the AEA violated the Immigration and Nationality Act, the Foreign Affairs Reform and Restructuring Act, and the Fifth Amendment. They sought a writ of habeas corpus releasing them from detention, as well as injunctive and declaratory relief. The case was assigned to District Judge Fernando Rodriguez.

This action was spurred by the U.S. Supreme Court's decision in J.G.G. v. Trump [../../../../case/46232/] that challenges to removals under the AEA must be brought in a habeas petition. The Court in that case vacated a temporary restraining order ("TRO") against removal of the plaintiffs because it found the venue, the District Court for the District of Columbia, to be inappropriate, since habeas petitions should be brought in the district of confinement.

Along with their habeas petition, the petitioners also filed an emergency motion for a TRO and a separate motion to certify the class. The same day the Court ordered that the petitioners were not to be removed from the United States or the Southern District of Texas while the case proceeded. A hearing was held on April 11, after which the Court issued a TRO set to expire on April 25, 2025. In addition, Judge Rodriguez ordered the plaintiffs to file a motion for a preliminary injunction by April 16, with briefing set to conclude on April 23 and a hearing scheduled for April 24, 2025.

On Thursday, April 24, 2025, Judge Rodriguez held a hearing and extended the TRO to Friday, May 2.

On Thursday, May 1, Judge Rodriguez first held that a class-like procedure was available under habeas, and then certified a class of Venezuelan aliens, 14 years old or older, who have not been naturalized, who Respondents have designated or in the future designate as alien enemies under [President's March 15 Executive Order], and who are detained or reside in the Southern District of Texas."

Then he entered a permanent injunction preventing the government from detaining, transferring, or removing J.A.V., J.G.G., W.G.H., and the members of the certified class, under the Alien Enemies Act and the Executive Order. He held:

While the [President's] Proclamation references that TdA members have harmed lives in the United States and engage in crime, the Proclamation does not suggest that they have done so through an organized armed attack, or that Venezuela has threatened or attempted such an attack through TdA members.  As a result, the Proclamation also falls short of describing a “predatory incursion” as that concept was understood at the time of the AEA’s enactment. . . . For these reasons, the Court concludes that the President’s invocation of the AEA through the Proclamation exceeds the scope of the statute and, as a result, is unlawful.  Respondents do not possess the lawful authority under the AEA, and based on the Proclamation, to detain Venezuelan aliens, transfer them within the United States, or remove them from the country.

On June 27, respondents appealed this decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit (Case No. 25-40400).

This case is ongoing
target_paragraph: This is one of several class action challenges to the Trump Administration's use of the Alien Enemies Act ("AEA") to circumvent removal procedures and deport Venezuelan nationals without due process. You can see all of the cases here [../../../../search/case/?advanced_search=true&plaintiff_description=Alien+Enemies+Act&ordering=-summary_approved_date].

annotation.explanation: April 9, 2025
Petition for writ of habeas corpus to challenge detention/removal under the Alien Enemies Act (habeas as the required vehicle per J.G.G. v. Trump).

Appeal: Respondents (President Donald J. Trump, the Department of Justice, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), the Department of State, and the El Valle Detention Facility) appealed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.
Plaintiff: J.A.V., a Venezuelan man and habeas petitioner held at the El Valle Detention Facility (a Texas ICE facility).
Plaintiff: J.G.G., a Venezuelan man and habeas petitioner held at the El Valle Detention Facility (a Texas ICE facility).
Plaintiff: W.G.H., a Venezuelan man and habeas petitioner held at the El Valle Detention Facility (a Texas ICE facility).

Defendant: Department of Justice.
Defendant: Department of Homeland Security (DHS).
Defendant: Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).
Defendant: Department of State.
Defendant: El Valle Detention Facility, the Texas ICE facility where the petitioners are being held.
April 9, 2025: The Court ordered that the petitioners were not to be removed from the United States or the Southern District of Texas while the case proceeded.

On April 9, 2025, three Venezuelan detainees at El Valle Detention Facility filed an ACLU-represented habeas petition in the Southern District of Texas against the President, DOJ, DHS/ICE, State, and the detention facility.
Petition for writ of habeas corpus filed on April 9, 2025 (S.D. Tex.).

annotation.explanation: Challenge to the Administration's invocation of the Alien Enemies Act and related Presidential Proclamation as unlawful (ultra vires).
ACLU
March 15, 2025: President Trump issued a proclamation declaring the United States was “under invasion” by Tren de Aragua and invoking the AEA.

The Administration’s actions were based on a March 15, 2025 presidential proclamation invoking the AEA due to an asserted invasion by Tren de Aragua; the AEA is described as a wartime removal authority.

target:
This is one of several class action challenges to the Trump Administration's use of the Alien Enemies Act ("AEA") to circumvent removal procedures and deport Venezuelan nationals without due process. You can see all of the cases here [../../../../search/case/?advanced_search=true&plaintiff_description=Alien+Enemies+Act&ordering=-summary_approved_date].

target:
This is one of several class action challenges to the Trump Administration's use of the Alien Enemies Act ("AEA") to circumvent removal procedures and deport Venezuelan nationals without due process. You can see all of the cases here [../../../../search/case/?advanced_search=true&plaintiff_description=Alien+Enemies+Act&ordering=-summary_approved_date].

On April 9, 2025, three Venezuelan men filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus in the United States District Court for the Southern District of Texas. They named as respondents President Donald J. Trump, the Department of Justice, the Department of Homeland Security (“DHS”), Immigration and Customs Enforcement (“ICE”), the Department of State, and the El Valle Detention Facility, the Texas ICE facility where the petitioners are being held.

Represented by the ACLU, the petitioners challenged the Administration’s invocation of the AEA to remove them from the United States without any opportunity for a hearing or judicial review. The AEA is a wartime measure that authorizes the removal of citizens from countries with whom the United States is at war. On March 15, 2025, President Trump issued a proclamation declaring that the United States was “under invasion” by Tren de Aragua, a Venezuelan gang and designated foreign terrorist organization, and invoking the AEA.

The petitioners alleged that this use of the AEA violated the Immigration and Nationality Act, the Foreign Affairs Reform and Restructuring Act, and the Fifth Amendment. They sought a writ of habeas corpus releasing them from detention, as well as injunctive and declaratory relief. The case was assigned to District Judge Fernando Rodriguez.

This action was spurred by the U.S. Supreme Court's decision in J.G.G. v. Trump [../../../../case/46232/] that challenges to removals under the AEA must be brought in a habeas petition. The Court in that case vacated a temporary restraining order ("TRO") against removal of the plaintiffs because it found the venue, the District Court for the District of Columbia, to be inappropriate, since habeas petitions should be brought in the district of confinement.

Along with their habeas petition, the petitioners also filed an emergency motion for a TRO and a separate motion to certify the class. The same day the Court ordered that the petitioners were not to be removed from the United States or the Southern District of Texas while the case proceeded. A hearing was held on April 11, after which the Court issued a TRO set to expire on April 25, 2025. In addition, Judge Rodriguez ordered the plaintiffs to file a motion for a preliminary injunction by April 16, with briefing set to conclude on April 23 and a hearing scheduled for April 24, 2025.

On Thursday, April 24, 2025, Judge Rodriguez held a hearing and extended the TRO to Friday, May 2.

On Thursday, May 1, Judge Rodriguez first held that a class-like procedure was available under habeas, and then certified a class of Venezuelan aliens, 14 years old or older, who have not been naturalized, who Respondents have designated or in the future designate as alien enemies under [President's March 15 Executive Order], and who are detained or reside in the Southern District of Texas."

Then he entered a permanent injunction preventing the government from detaining, transferring, or removing J.A.V., J.G.G., W.G.H., and the members of the certified class, under the Alien Enemies Act and the Executive Order. He held:

While the [President's] Proclamation references that TdA members have harmed lives in the United States and engage in crime, the Proclamation does not suggest that they have done so through an organized armed attack, or that Venezuela has threatened or attempted such an attack through TdA members.  As a result, the Proclamation also falls short of describing a “predatory incursion” as that concept was understood at the time of the AEA’s enactment. . . . For these reasons, the Court concludes that the President’s invocation of the AEA through the Proclamation exceeds the scope of the statute and, as a result, is unlawful.  Respondents do not possess the lawful authority under the AEA, and based on the Proclamation, to detain Venezuelan aliens, transfer them within the United States, or remove them from the country.

On June 27, respondents appealed this decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit (Case No. 25-40400).

This case is ongoing
target_paragraph: On Thursday, April 24, 2025, Judge Rodriguez held a hearing and extended the TRO to Friday, May 2.

annotation.explanation: Through May 2, 2025: TRO extended.
April 24, 2025: Judge Rodriguez extended the TRO to Friday, May 2.
May 2: Extended TRO expiration date.
On April 24, 2025, the court extended the TRO to May 2.
TRO extended on April 24, 2025 to May 2, 2025, following a hearing.
Hearing held April 24, 2025; TRO extended to May 2, 2025.
April 24, 2025: Court extended the TRO to May 2, 2025.

annotation.explanation: Plaintiff: Certified class of Venezuelan aliens, 14 years old or older, not naturalized, designated (now or in future) as alien enemies under [President's March 15 Executive Order], and detained or residing in the Southern District of Texas.

On May 1, 2025, the court held that a class-like procedure is available in habeas and certified a class defined as Venezuelan aliens (14+ years, not naturalized) designated as alien enemies under the March 15 Executive Order and detained or residing in the Southern District of Texas.

May 1, 2025: Court granted class certification (after holding a class-like procedure is available in habeas), certifying a class of Venezuelan aliens 14+ not naturalized, designated as alien enemies under the March 15 Executive Order, detained or residing in the Southern District of Texas.
